aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident in Newport, Vermont
The accident occurred in Newport, Vermont.
The accident occurred on June 7, 2014, at 17:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Piper PA-28-140.
The defining event of the accident was an aerodynamic stall/spin.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was ERA14LA285.
The aircraft registration was N5169T.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 2 occupants in the aircraft.
No injuries resulted from the accident.
The pilot was returning to his home airport after a local flight.
The local flight lasted about 2 hours.
The pilot conducted a go-around on his first attempted landing.
The pilot was "high and fast" on the second landing attempt.
The runway was equipped with a 2-light precision approach path indicator.
The precision approach path indicator would have given guidance to touch down within the first one-third of the runway.
The airplane touched down about 3,000 feet down the 3,998-foot runway.
The pilot applied full power to abort the landing.
After lifting off, the airplane pitched up.
According to the pilot, the engine failed.
The airplane was approximately 200 feet above ground level when it banked left.
The airplane settled back toward the ground.
The airplane impacted the ground.
The airplane slid to a stop about 850 feet off the end of the runway.
The pilot exited the wreckage immediately after the accident.
The pilot was observed leaving the airport after the accident.
A postaccident examination of the engine was conducted.
A test run of the engine was performed.
The examination and test run revealed no evidence of anomalies that would have precluded normal engine operation.
According to a witness, she observed the pilot on the morning of the accident.
The witness observed the pilot consume 12 to 16 alcoholic beverages.
The alcoholic beverages were consumed between 0745 and 1230.
The pilot left at 1230 to meet his passenger for the flight.
The Vermont State Police made contact with the pilot at his residence after the accident.
The pilot refused a breathalyzer test.
The airplane likely entered an aerodynamic stall.
The pilot failed to adequately maintain airspeed after the aborted landing.
The pilot failed to adequately maintain pitch control after the aborted landing.
The pilot's failure to maintain airspeed and pitch control was likely related to his consumption of alcohol.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Newport, Vermont

## Date & Time: 
June 7, 2014, 17:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Piper PA-28-140

## Defining Event:
Aerodynamic stall/spin

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
ERA14LA285

## Registration:
N5169T

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

The pilot was returning to his home airport after a local flight that lasted about 2 hours. On his first attempted landing, the pilot conducted a go-around. The pilot said that he was "high and fast" on the second attempt, even though the runway was equipped with a 2-light precision approach path indicator which would have given the pilot guidance to touch down with the first one-third of the runway. The airplane touched down about 3,000 feet down the 3,998-foot runway. The pilot then applied full power to abort the landing. After lifting off, the airplane pitched up, and, according to the pilot, the engine failed. About 200 feet above ground level, the airplane banked left and settled back toward the ground; it then impacted the ground and slid to a stop about 850 feet off the end of the runway. Immediately after the accident, the pilot exited the wreckage and was observed leaving the airport.

A postaccident examination and test run of the engine revealed no evidence of any anomalies that would have precluded normal engine operation. According to a witness, on the morning of the accident, she observed the pilot consume 12 to 16 alcoholic beverages between 0745 and 1230 when the pilot left to meet his passenger for the flight. After the accident, the Vermont State Police made contact with the pilot at his residence, where he refused a breathalyzer test. Given the airplane's performance during and after the pitch up, and the absence of any indications of an engine anomaly, the airplane likely entered an aerodynamic stall; the pilot's failure to adequately maintain airspeed and pitch control after the aborted landing, which resulted in the stall, was likely related to his consumption of alcohol.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

---
